header_summary:
The recent discussions within the Bitcoin development community have shed light on significant advancements and explorations in the technology's ecosystem. A notable update is the release of Bitcoin Core's new version, v28.3rc2, which is positioned as a release candidate indicating its importance in the development cycle, with binaries available for download and preliminary release notes provided to detail the changes and improvements ([Bitcoin Core](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.3/test.rc2/)). Another discussion focuses on an experiment testing the compact block relay performance in the Bitcoin network, demonstrating a 90% success rate in block reconstruction, which suggests potential for enhancing network efficiency and scalability ([Uncensored Tech Substack](https://uncensoredtech.substack.com/p/compact-block-relay-with-extra-pool)).

Additionally, the release of Bitcoin Core version 29.2 introduces bug fixes, performance enhancements, and updated translations aimed at improving user experience, with the development team encouraging community feedback through their GitHub issue tracker ([Bitcoin Core](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-29.2/)). On a different note, debates around the implementation of STARK on Bitcoin highlight the trade-offs between proving speed, proof size, and verification efficiency, exploring avenues to optimize these parameters for better scalability and efficiency within the Bitcoin protocol ([DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proposal-op-stark-verify-native-stark-proof-verification-in-bitcoin-script/2056/3)).

Lastly, discussions contrast the operational frameworks and economic implications of using the Lightning Network (LN) versus sidechains for transactions, with a focus on the technical and financial barriers that may influence user preference for sidechains due to their lower costs and higher transactional flexibility ([DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ln-routing-and-caveats/2003/5)). This compilation of conversations underscores the ongoing efforts within the Bitcoin development community to refine, optimize, and expand the capabilities of the Bitcoin network, highlighting both technological advancements and areas requiring further exploration and debate.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.3 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core introduced version v28.3rc2, available for download on their website.

recent_posts.title: Compact block relay in knots using the extra pool
recent_posts.summary:
- A developer tested compact block relay in Bitcoin using a custom Knots node setup.
- The experiment achieved a 90% success rate in block reconstruction, showing effective mempool synchronization.
- The findings, aimed at improving Bitcoin's scalability, are open for community feedback on Uncensored Tech Substack and GitHub.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.2 Released
recent_posts.summary:

recent_posts.title: Proposal: OP_STARK_VERIFY - Native STARK Proof Verification in Bitcoin Script
recent_posts.summary:
- Implementing STARK on Bitcoin requires balancing proving speed, proof size, and verification efficiency.
- Various proof compression strategies exist, with the fastest offering 500KB size and 25ms verification time.
- On-chain proof costs involve significant transactions, with alternatives showing comparable total sizes and costs.

recent_posts.title: LN routing and caveats
recent_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Network's direct transfer limitations contrast with sidechains' more flexible transactions.
- High fees and channel constraints on the Lightning Network deter users compared to direct blockchain transactions.
- Technical issues with the Lightning Network highlight sidechains as a lower-cost, more flexible alternative.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners have adopted new mempool policies, enhancing transaction and network operations.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation times, improving network efficiency and reducing orphan rates.
- Strategies like weak blocks and template sharing are being explored to improve network robustness and transaction privacy.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A stealthier BGP hijacking variant exposes significant Bitcoin network vulnerabilities, enabling eclipse attacks.
- Attackers could hijack Bitcoin traffic by controlling Autonomous Systems and evading detection through BGP community usage.
- Proposed mitigations include peer rotation, dynamic port negotiation, and prioritizing connections to RPKI-protected peers.
